RSV infections peaked towards the end of the rainy season during the first and third year of our study. we explored whether there could be an association between preceding rainfall and RSV infections, and by introducing a 2-month lag after peak precipitation, such an association could indeed be identified. a strong association with relative humidity was also found for hMPV infections. we detected more than one virus in 3.3% of the virus-positive NPA specimens. this is similar to what is reported using molecular methods detecting the same viruses as in our study. the frequency of viral co-detections varies widely and depends on the number of diagnostic methods applied [59] and the number of pathogens tested for [58] despite the high sensitivity and specificity of the Hexaplex Plus assay, we may have underestimated the number of viral infections. we observed a large month-to-month variation in the proportion of CAP cases from whom we identified a respiratory RNA virus. pneumoniae has been suggested to play a role in the development of virus-associated pneumonia in children in hospital. the monthly number of cases where we did not identify any virus was particularly pronounced in the CAP epidemic. there is abundant evidence that infection with influenza viruses predisposes for pneumococcal disease. authors declare that they have no competing interests. authors' contributions MM participated in the protocol design, planning, field implementation, microbiological analyses, data management and analysis. the authors of the study had no role in study design, data collection, data analysis, data interpretation, or writing of the report. the authors had no role in study design, data collection, data analysis, data interpretation, or writing of the report.
